items.text: I am a second-year master's student living in Tokyo.
I started competitive programming when I entered university, which sparked my interest in personal development. Gradually, my interest shifted to large-scale service development.
In university, I belonged to a Computer Vision lab and conducted research on knowledge distillation-based Federated Learning. In graduate school, I am focusing further on FL.
I am gaining experience as a student intern at various companies, large and small. Recently, I have been interested in Platform Engineering and MLOps.
My hobby is server maintenance in the lab. My goals for 2025 are to have a paper accepted in a journal and to contribute to and present at many conferences.

items.title: Getting Started with Chrome Extension Development in React
textList: Published a beginner's guide to developing Chrome extensions with React and TypeScript, as there were no systematic documents available.
Learn by developing a practical translation Chrome extension like DeepL in a hands-on format.
Ranked #1 on Zenn's Trending Books (February 2023). A revised edition was released in February 2024, and the second edition in March 2025.

items.title: Development of a Resource Label Monitoring Tool for Cost Management in the Cloud
textList: My work as an intern at CyberAgent was featured on the Developers Blog.
I developed a tool to monitor resource labels to facilitate cost management in ABEMA's large-scale cloud environment.
The source code and Terraform for deployment are available on GitHub.

items.title: A Study on a Knowledge Distillation Method Using Energy Score to Reduce Communication Volume in Federated Learning
textList: Received the Best Poster Award (top 7%) at the student poster session of the IEICE General Conference 2024 held at Hiroshima University.

In a distillation-based federated learning method, we introduced an out-of-distribution detection score for the first time to aggregate only predictions for well-learned data, successfully reducing communication volume and improving learning efficiency.
I further developed the presentation content and wrote it as my graduation thesis.

items.title: Increasing the Memory Limit of OOMed CronJobs 'Just Right' to Reduce Unnecessary Billing and Incident Response
textList: My work as an intern at M3 was featured on the tech blog.

I developed 'broom', a Custom Controller that increases the memory limit 'just right' when an OOM occurs in a Kubernetes CronJob, aiming to solve problems from both cloud billing and incident response aspects.
Broom is open-sourced on GitHub and is still under active development.

items.title: Migrating the Log Infrastructure from Fluentd to Fluent Bit and Implementing a Monitoring Tool
textList: My work as an intern at Mirrativ was featured on the tech blog.
I carefully documented the investigation of the cause of log loss in the existing infrastructure, the migration from Fluentd to Fluent Bit, and the implementation of a Fluent Bit monitoring tool.
It ranked #2 on Hatena Bookmark's hot entries (Technology).
